He was so kind and patient and never gave up looking for me. The ring was no where to be seen. I was convinced Iaposd lost it forever I was ready to have a breakdown. However in his very last handful of mud there was my ring. He has no idea how much he made my day. I was so so lucky that he managed to find it for me. Literally in tears now when I think it over. story: :root It doesn’t feel like work! - mum spices things up with surprising new careerAs KFC launches its limited edition Zinger Popcorn Bucket, we celebrate the thrill of trying something newAdvertorialByLaura Tait:,  Oct When it comes to decision making do you play it safe, or seek out fun and adventure  If you fancy yourself as a thrill seeker, then Zinger Popcorn is for you. To celebrate the launch of Zinger Popcorn Bucket - available for a limited time only - we decided to champion people who like to spice things up, including Hannah Murphy, . When she reached a career crossroads in , Hannah struck out on a new adventurous course, and almost a decade on has no regrets about her bold decision. When I was made redundant from my eight-year career as a flight attendant, flying both domestically and between the UK and Japan, I saw it as an opportunity set myself a new challenge, and have new adventures, says Hannah who lives in Southampton with her husband and three children, Angelina, , Archie,  and Adriana, five. At the time I was a single mum of one after my previous relationship ended, and the ‘sensible’ decision would have been to take a - desk job, something stable but didnapost challenge me. That’s just not me though, I have to love what I do and find joy in it every day. Instead, Hannah trained as a fitness instructor and began to incorporate a hula hoop into her training. It wasn’t just a useful exercise tool, great for toning and core strength, it was so much fun. The moment I started hula hooping, I was transported back to my childhood, it was really liberating. As word got out about Hannah’s hula hooping prowess, friends and family began to ask for lessons, followed by requests from local schools for Hannah to come in and teach children how to hula hoop.  It snowballed and before I knew it, I had so much interest in hula hooping fitness classes, I had to train other instructors to help me. I went on to create a training programme called Globe Fit and today I have teachers all around the world, from Australia to America, all teaching my programme. I love teaching hula hooping, particularly adults, because they might start off a bit self-conscious and inhibited but soon their inner child is released and they just go for it! I’ve taught people aged from teenagers to eighty-year-olds. Last year, I hosted the first ever world hula hooping championship, which will be taking place again later this year. After launching the UKaposs first hula hooping championship in , which took place in Fareham, Hampshire, Hannah decided to go global in . Not even a pandemic could stop her with the event going virtual and around twenty-five competitors, women and men of all ages and abilities, taking part from as far afield as India, America and Australia. I had a  of four judges, including John Parnell aka Hoop Guy who appeared on Britainaposs Got Talent in . Competitors submitted videos of themselves performing with their hoop, and were marked on everything from skill to tricks they could do, with the  judging the videos.  The second world championship will take place in December this year, again virtually, and I hope to have even more people taking part. It’s amazing to be a part of people experiencing something new and fun, it doesn’t feel like work! Hannah’s story is a great example of how le can get better when you try something new, soyou already love Popcorn chicken - tasty pops of  per cent chicken breast, perfect to nibble on by themselves or as a side - then itaposs time to turn up the heat. title: ms great britain winner nearly
story: :root Exclusive: Ms Great Britain winner nearly died as crippling anorexia saw her weight plummetApril Banbury, , dropped to three-and-a-half stone as she struggled with the eating disorder but is now a mental health charity ambassador helping young peopleApril wins Ms Great Britain Image: Graham Stone REX ShutterstockByPhil CardySenior reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsStunning April Banbury beamed with delight when she was crowned a beauty queen – but behind the smiles there were years of pain. Few would have appreciated the anguish and suffering she had endured growing up and how she nearly died from anorexia as a teenager. Now the bridal design company owner is helping others fight potentially deadly eating disorders. At age , April spent a week in hospital after her weight plunged to three-and-a-half stone. She traces her weight problems to when she was eight. Her parents orced and she felt rejected. April would throw her lunch into the bushes on the way to school and only nibble on crackers. At meal times she would sit staring at her plate for hours, until dad Ian, an Olympic cyclist who won a  bronze in Montreal, would lose his patience and send her to bed. She finally overcame her issues when she was . She won Ms Great Britain , a contest for women aged  and over. April, , who is ft in, now weighs a healthy eight-and-a-half stone and visits schools as an ambassador for eating disorder charity SEEDto talk to young people about their problems and mental health issues. “At my lowest point I weighed three-and-a-half stone,” said April, who was raised by Ian and her nan Dorothy. “There’s a picture of me on a bicycle and I look so gaunt, I was in the worst place possible. Dad took that picture to show how bad it was. “It was very distressing for Dad and Nan. I ended up in hospital for over a week, I ­nearly died. That was the wake-up call I needed.” Dorothy inspired her recovery but it still took April several years to start eating properly. She said: “Nan sat me down and made me watch a film about a young girl with ­anorexia who died. “Nan said she didn’t want that to be me. After hospital I still found it % dficult to eat, it took me years to eat.  “I was about , it was a long slow process. Anorexia is a mental disorder, a mind over matter thing. You have to train the mind to no longer play tricks and that food is no longer the enemy. “I’ve had counselling. I had so much therapy well into early adult le, Dad made sure I spoke to the therapist and had regular weight check-ins. “Even on the road to recovery my body mass index was at a point of looking anorexic. I was eating and eating and not gaining weight, I was trying to recover. My family knew I was but I had a ­naturally fast metabolism. “My family made my meals, everything was monitored. My absolute favourite now is a Sunday dinner, I love it, beef or chicken.”  A record number of children and young people with a potentially le-threatening eating disorder are waiting for treatment in England. In April to June,  patients were on stand by for urgent treatment, up from  at the same time last year. A further , patients were waiting for routine treatment, up from  a year earlier. April, who appeared on Channel ’s The Bachelor and ITV’s The Cabins, has found it is not just children who are fixated with how they look. She said: “In my day job as a bridal designer, I see so many beautul women who are always ­talking about losing weight and looking perfect and it absolutely breaks my heart.” She posted videos online during lockdown to reach out to those who are struggling. April has had many positive messages since and, after lockdown, was approached by a woman in public, who told her: “You don’t realise the good you’ve done.”The Daily Mirror is launching our new campaign HeadStrong: Better Mental Health For All. We’re calling for:Early Access Mental Health Hubs for under s to be rolled out across the country, with at least one for each trust. Waiting times to be cut so people actually start treatment with a professional within four weeks The Govt to fill in the gaps in care - an end of red tape which means many don’t fit the set criteria to get help plus , more mental health staffCompulsory Mental Health education lessons in schools, plus paid counsellors in schools and care homesWant to help  Write to your MP and ask them to support the current Early Day Motion  to debate mental health and the pandemic in parliament.Access the Mirror’s mental health resource hubShe said: “For someone to come up to me in the street, someone I had never met before, was amazing. It meant everything. For me to be able to help others who may not have recovered was the icing on the cake.” SEED chief exec Shelley Perry said of April: “SEED Lancashire and Breathe have thoroughly enjoyed working with someone that has such a passion for helping and supporting anyone suffering with mental health and eating disorders. “She’s a fantastic public figure that highlights the journey through recovery and helps to guide anyone needing support into the right place. We are grateful for the work that we do together.”  Jenny Cairns, SEED ­marketing and ­communication volunteer, added: “April has a good heart and a willingness to help other people. “She has such a passion for helping people. This is something she’s been wanting to do for a while, she has always had a drive for that. If she’d have had this at school when she was younger, it might have helped her at an earlier stage.”How to get help: If you are struggling or you are worried about a loved one, contact Samaritans on . For more advice visit nhs.uk mental-health or www.mind.org.uk information-support coronavirus See more HeadStrong Lives, including a Childrenaposs special with child psychiatrist Lopa Winters and Mumfluencer Lorna Cobbett , Samaritans Advice Clinic, and a Menaposs Mental Health Special with Alastair Campbell and BDD sufferer and War Paint For Men and JAAQ founder Danny Gray atfacebook dailymirror videos Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON AnorexiaMental healthEating disordersTeenagersTherapyBeauty contests" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. I had to get my phone quick and took a couple of pictures.Photos taken by Amanda show the council worker wearing a clownaposs multi coloured curly wig and spongy red nose. Heaposs boss, he deserves an award. story: :root Mums bump so small at  weeks that nobody believed she was pregnantCourtney-Jayne, , posted her unusually small tummy on TikTok, admitting that nobody actually believed she was pregnant so far into her pregnancyCourtney-Jayne, , posted her unusually small tummy on TikTokByTom Ambrose:,  Oct | commentsA mum claims nobody believed she was expecting after sharing a picture of her tiny baby bump at  weeks pregnant.Courtney-Jayne, , posted her unusually small tummy on TikTok, admitting that nobody actually believed she was pregnant so far into her pregnancy, The Sun reported.The video went viral, gaining a remarkable two million views, after Courtney captioned it: Me trying to convince people Iaposm  weeks pregnant. Some viewers struggled to believe she was due in little over five weeks, with others hilariously saying she looked like she was simply full after a meal. Commenting on the video, in which Courtney lts her t-shirt to reveal to tiny baby bump, one person said: I look like that after a bowl of spaghetti. Another user quipped: “Iaposm bigger than that now and I had my first baby  years ago. I’m bigger than that now and I had my first baby  years ago, joked another TikTok user, while a fourth person added: I looked like that at four weeks! Courtney, whose due date was in late September, has since revealed that she eventually had the baby after  weeks of pregnancy. Sharing a video of her bulging belly shortly before going into labour, she said: All the way through my pregnancy I was so small and didn’t have much of a bump. Then suddenly at  weeks he popped out so I have a bump for my last two weeks.In other baby news, a woman gave birth to a baby boy on a flight from London to India after going into labour two months early.Maria Philip, originally from Pathanamthitta, Kerala, India, was flying to Kochi from Heathrow on  October, but she started to experience pains shortly after takeoff. The plane had to stop in Germany, were mother and child were taken to a nearby hospital, with the airline vowing to fly them home when theyaposre well enough. The mum-to-be was seven months pregnant so wasnapost expecting to welcome her baby until later this year. Luckily she had the help of two doctors and four nurses who happened to be on board. news uk-news mums-world-fell-apart-coffee-"Scots tot rings chemo bell after  weeks of treatmentByKathleen SpeirsReporterGraeme Murray:,  Oct | commentsA mumaposs aposworld fell apartapos after aposcoffee spotsapos found on her sonaposs body led to a le-threatening brain tumour. Colette Cheape has urged parents to be on the look out after watching her brave son Odhrán go through  weeks of chemotherapy and multiple surgeries in just under four years. He was just a few months old when aposmilky brown birth marksapos started appearing across his body in late . After being taken to get them checked out, he was diagnosed with Neurofibromatosis type  . This is a genetic condition that, in serious cases, causes a range of conditions including tumours, body deformities, blindness and learning dficulties. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Worried parents, Colette,  and Richard, , were told his case was at that stage still mild, meaning his condition was stable for the time being but had to be closely monitored. But in April , Odhrán started struggling with bowel movements and extreme tiredness It prompted an MRI scan at Glasgowaposs Royal Hospital for Children. Doctors then told Richard and Colette, from Kilsyth, the aposworst news imaginableapos. Odhrán had a brain tumour as a result of NF and to stand any chance of survival he urgently needed risky surgery to drain fluid the next day.Colette, whoaposs also mum to Aoe, , and one-year-old Una, told the Daily Record : When we were told the NF had resulted in a brain tumour our world fell apart.We were in lockdown where only Richard could stay in hospital with Odhrán, I felt so helpless. Doctors said he was, at that point, critically ill. It was so tough. For the next year and a half the family watched little Odhran fight off the condition. His second surgery to aposdebulkapos the large tumour on the brain, one week after the drainage op, was incredibly daunting in itself. Colette added: There was a chance heaposd not survive, come out blind or brain damaged, it was terrying. But we had no other option.  The procedure successfully removed % of the tumour and after a month-long recovery, where the toddler learned to walk again, Odhrán was reunited with his sisters at home. But in late May  medics discovered his tumour aposwasnapost behavingapos and put him on a -week course of chemotherapy, to eliminate the risk of it ever posing a danger again. On September  this year, one day before his fourth birthday, Odhrán finished chemotherapy for good. The family hosted a garden party to mark the special occasion where, surrounded by family and friends, the beaming youngster rang the bell to official mark the end of his treatment. To say thank you to hospital staff, gran Marie Brady launched an GoFundMe page, which has so far raised over £,. Colette also created a public Instagram account to document Odhránaposs recovery journey and raise awareness about aposcoffee spotsapos, formally known as Cafe Au Lait marks, and the condition NF. According to the Childhood Tumour Trust Neurofibromatosis Type is more prevalent than Cystic Fibrosis, Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy, and Huntingtons Disease combined. Almost all NF patientswill have six or more Cafe Au Lait marks on their skin. She said: We are so grateful to the childrenaposs hospital, we donapost know where weaposd be without them. Odhrán loving weekly hospital chemo visits is testament to them. With the Instragram, I wanted to get the word out there. NF is more common that Cystic Fibrosis yet not that many people know about it. “We hope we can help to raise awareness of the signs of NF in order to help children receive early diagnosis and therefore the necessary specialist care.”For more information on Neurofibromatosis visit the NHS website or the Childhood Tumour TrustYou can donate to the familyaposs Childrenaposs Hospital fundraiser through their official JustGiving page.Comment MORE ON NHSChildrens HospitalHospitalsBrain Tumours" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: :root Exclusive: Prince Harry and Meghan Markles new pal is m tycoon who sold self-help bookHarry and Meghan are said to have made several visits to Bill Guthy, who donated thousands to an anti-immigration Republican who vowed to help Donald Trump build the Mexican border wallHarry and Meghan are said to have made several visits to Bill Guthy Image: SplashNewsByPatrick Hill:,  Oct | commentsPrince Harry and his we Meghan have become pals with a tycoon who made a fortune flogging a self-help book called Think and Grow Rich.The couple are said to have made several visits to Bill Guthy, who donated thousands to an anti-immigration Republican who vowed to help Donald Trump build the Mexican border wall.Guthy – worth million – backed Jimmy “Trumpbacker” Crumpacker, an anti-abortionist who is pro-gun lobby.Crumpacker has said on Facebook : “I’m a gun-packing, Trump-backing, send-them-packing conservative.”The Duke and Duchess of Sussex have both slammed Trump – with Meghan labelling the ex-president “isive and misygnostic”. Guthy has supported Democrat causes too, but backing Crumpacker seems hugely at odds with the royals’ views. The tycoon is also a gas-guzzling driver who let eco-warriors Harry and Meghan fly on his company’s private jet.  That trip, last month, came after a string of public engagements in New York by the couple, who say they are on a mission to “build a better world”.Since stepping down as senior royals they have launched the charity foundation Archewell – while also netting lucrative deals with the likes of Netflix and Spoty.A source told the Sunday Mirror: “Harry and Meghan have become regular visitors to Bill Guthy’s estate in Carpinteria. Bill is one of le’s winners. “He certainly knows all about how to make a buck. Guthy has made donations to Democrat campaigns for Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton, but his backing of The Trumpbacker seems to point to a vastly dferent view to that of Harry and Meghan. “It appears the main thing the three of them have in common is a talent for making big money deals.”  Guthy lives on a vast estate in Carpinteria, north of Los Angeles and  miles from the home of Harry, , Meghan, , and their children Archie, two, and baby Lilibet. He also has a £million pad in Beverly Hills, with tennis court and pool. Aged , he drives a mpg Cadillac Escalade ESV. That, plus his support of Crumpacker, may spark interesting chats with the royals. Records show that he donated , in  to the Oregon Republican’s failed bid to be elected to Congress. Crumpacker vowed to protect gun rights and the unborn and to “stand with Trump, get the economy moving and build the wall”. Guthy’s earlier Republican donations included , to the  Bush Cheney campaign. Meghan spoke out against Trump in a TV interview in . She said: “Trump is isive, think about female voters alone. In  the Republican Party lost the female vote by  points and with as mis-ogynistic as Trump is, and so vocal about it, that’s a huge chunk of it.” Harry, meanwhile, told a prank caller who impersonated Greta Thunberg: “The mere fact Donald Trump is pushing the coal industry so big, he has blood on his hands. The effect that has on the climate. Trump will want to meet you to make him look better, but he won’t want a discussion about climate change because you will outsmart him.” Guthy and business partner Greg Renker launch-ed their firm in  after being inspired by Think and Grow Rich, written by Napoleon Hill in . The pals used savings to promote the guide via TV infomercials. Sales of the book, and a tape of Hill’s lectures, netted nearly million.  One of the best-selling self-help books of all time, it urges readers to believe anything is possible, telling wannabe millionaires to write down their aims on a piece of paper and read them back to themselves morning and night. Guthy-Renker has gone on to work with the likes of Heidi Klum, Jessica Simpson, Cindy Crawford, Jenner Lopez and Kelly Clarkson. story: :root Schoolboy, , driving BMW on M caused horror motorway crash with lorryCristian Pompa, , pleaded guilty at Leicester Crown Court to causing serious injury by dangerous driving and was sentenced to  months detention following the crashWreckage at the scene of the crash on the M Image: Leicester LiveBySuzy Gibson:,  Oct | commentsAn underage driver ran a lorry off the road, leaving its driver stuck in the twisted wreckage. Cristian Pompa had been weaving in and out of traffic in a red BMW on the M near junction  on Thursday March  last year.The -year-old struck a car from behind, sending the vehicle and the woman inside crashing into the central reservation, reports Leicester Mercury. The smash wrote off her vehicle and caused her soft tissue injuries which required physiotherapy treatment. The boyaposs car then crashed into the front offside of a Volvo heavy goods vehicle.  David Earl, prosecuting, said: The impact wrenched the steering wheel from the lorry driveraposs hands as the steering jammed. The vehicle left the carriageway, went down a bank and tipped onto its side. The driver was trapped in his cab and had to be cut out by the fire service. The HGV was damaged beyond repair.. The prosecutor said: The lorry driveraposs injuries included three fractures to his spine, a broken right scapula and soft tissue damage to his shoulder and back. The pain was excruciating.He was off work for  weeks and has ongoing issues, including severe headaches and is still on painkillers.In a victim impact statement he said he suffers flashbacks and anxiety. Pompa, who has since turned , fled from the carnage but was arrested after his DNA was found on the blown airbag of his abandoned car. He pleaded guilty at Leicester Crown Court to causing serious injury by dangerous driving, Mr Earl said the lorry driver was also a carer for his we, who suffers from MS, and his injuries made it particularly dficult to look after her. She was traumatised by the incident and seeing him in hospital. The court heard that when arrested, Pompa, of Park Avenue, Tottenham, London - who has  non-dwelling burglaries and four thefts on his criminal record - gave a no comment interview and has never identied the driver of the red BMW who whisked him away from the crash scene.  Sentencing, Judge Robert Brown said: You were  years old and had no driving licence and should not have been behind the wheel of a car or driving down the M motorway. Your driving was appalling and whilst attempting a manoeuvre, squeezing between two vehicles, you caused a serious collision. The lorry driver was trapped and had to be rescued by others at the scene, who turned off his engine because he was unable to. There are ongoing consequences for him. Your vehicle stopped but instead of going back to see how the other drivers were you got into a car that had been following you and sped off. Fleeing the scene was utterly shameful. Iaposm told youaposre now remorseful. Priya Bakshi, mitigating, said Pompaaposs family were in court and his parents appreciated how serious the offence was. At the time Pompa was studying for his GCSEs and was hoping to do a mechanics college course having passed his exams. Miss Bakshi said Pompa was sorry and had since matured, now recognising the error of his ways. She added: Thereaposs nothing I can say to excuse what he did. He sayaposs aposIaposm guilty and I was , to say sorry is not enough andI could turn the clock back in time I would, I didnapost think of the consequences.aposI know I could have killed others and killed myself.aposPompa was sentenced to  months detention. He was banned from driving for two years and eight months. news uk-news so-many-were-dying-began-"Mirror Head Strong:  call centre worker shares mental health storyByMatt RoperFeatures writer:,  Oct | commentsA siren goes off in our control room when there’s a category  call, one where there’s an immediate threat to le. That alarm will go offsomeone’s not breathing. And during the Covid pandemic it felt like it was going off constantly. Being an ambulance dispatcher is already a stressful job, when every day you see and hear things that most people don’t see in their letimes. But during Covid, especially during the second and third waves, the call volume went through the roof. It was the worst thing I’ve seen in my le. Every call seemed to be either someone dying of Covid, or suffering with their mental health because of the pandemic. It was like that on repeat, and that takes its toll on you.Have you struggled with your mental health in lockdown  Email webnews@mirror to tell your story There were so many people who were dying, in their homes, at the supermarket. I’d sometimes spend two to four hours talking to a suicidal caller. A couple of people have even taken their own le while on the phone. I was shocked at how many calls I was taking from elderly people who were struggling. Normally they are the strong ones, the ones who always impressed me by just battling on, yet now they were having real problems with their mental health because they’d spent so much time on their own. I would think, ‘God, you remind me of my Nan, or my Grandad’. It was a really scary time.  When someone stops breathing we always send three resources - a manager, a paramedic and an ambulance - so there are enough people to save their le. But resources were started to get really stretched. I remember on one sht when I was dispatching during the second lockdown when so many people weren’t breathing that for the first time in my career I didn’t know what to do. It felt like all of our crews were already busy with other patients.The Daily Mirror is launching our new campaign HeadStrong: Better Mental Health For All. We’re calling for:Early Access Mental Health Hubs for under s to be rolled out across the country, with at least one for each trust. Waiting times to be cut so people actually start treatment with a professional within four weeks The Govt to fill in the gaps in care - an end of red tape which means many don’t fit the set criteria to get help plus , more mental health staffCompulsory Mental Health education lessons in schools, plus paid counsellors in schools and care homesWant to help  Write to your MP and ask them to support the current Early Day Motion  to debate mental health and the pandemic in parliament. In  my best friend, also an emergency dispatcher, took his own le. I took it badly, and my employers paid for therapy, which carried on into the pandemic and which helped me cope during the first wave. But those sessions were now over. When you’re spending so much time dealing with suicides and deaths, you become negative. I began to feel so low and unable to cope, like I was in a bottomless pit I couldn’t get out of. I started having anxiety attacks before going to work, and was vomiting before and after every sht. I worried constantlyI would have enough ambulances and crews, and about my staff too, who were terried. I felt like the worst person when I had to send them to a Covid patient as we weren’t quite sure what we were sending them to. Access the Mirror’s mental health resource hubIt got so bad that every time the emergency alarm went off I would jump, the noise was causing me so much anxiety. I was even hearing it in my head when I went home. After every sht I would call my friend and just start crying, even though I didn’t know exactly why I was crying. I started taking antidepressants but although they helped me sleep they just made me feel numb. I asked for more therapy sessions but I was declined because there were so many other staff on the waiting list for mental health support. I’m grateful for the therapy I did get though, the weekly phone calls with a psychologist made me a stronger person and I don’t know where I’d be without them.  It’s scary how many of my colleagues are dealing with mental health issues. They are some of the strongest people I’ve ever met, and many are messaging me to tell me they are struggling too. Mental health support in the emergency services has to be the best of the best, becauseyou can’t look after yourself how can you look after others  At the moment blue light staff generally receive six to  one-hour sessions of therapy, but in some cases that isn’t enough. I firmly believe we need more funding for mental health support at every level, but especially in the emergency services where we deal with le and death situations every day.How to get help: If you are struggling or you are worried about a loved one, contact Samaritans on . title: uk records lowest ever butterfly
story: :root UK records lowest ever butterfly numbers as climate crisis threatens insectsButterfly Conservation, which counted butterflies and moths between July  and August , said the results marked the lowest numbers since the Big Butterfly Count started years ago and called for urgent actionThe UK has recorded its lowest ever number of butterflies Image: Geoffrey Swaine REX ShutterstockByNada FarhoudEnvironment editor:,  Oct | commentsWhere have all the ­butterflies gone  This summer you may have noticed a lack of common blues or peacock butterflies in your garden or local park. In the latest warning for nature, the UK has recorded its lowest ever number in an annual survey of the insects.And the future looks even bleaker after ­scientists warned the decline could accelerate due to more extreme weather linked to climate change.Butterfly Conservation, which counted butterflies and moths between July  and August , said the results marked the lowest numbers since the Big Butterfly Count started years ago and called for urgent action. As well as being a vital part of the food chain, butterflies are signicant indicators of the health of the environment. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter The number of peacock butterflies fell by % compared with last year, while the common blue declined by %, speckled wood by % and small tortoiseshell by %. On average, nine butterflies or moths were spotted per -minute count by , volunteers, down from  in , and  in . A handful of species, including marbled white and ringlet, rose from low levels during last year’s count. Butterfly Conservation said heavy downpours in May, when England had the highest rainfall for that month since , hampered breeding and feeding.  “Butterflies don’t like rain at all, they’re coldblooded. Effectively they’re solar-powered,” the charity said. “With more climate ­change-related extreme weather likely, the impact on some of the UK’s most loved insects could be devastating.” The State of the UK’s Butterflies report, a scientic survey last published in , found three quarters of Britain’s ­butterflies had declined since . The large blue is an exception, with numbers growing since it was reintroduced in  via caterpillars from Sweden. Julie Williams, the charity’s chief ­executive, said: “The facts are clear. Nature is in crisis and we need urgent action, not just to prevent further species losses but to rebuild bioersity.” Comment MORE ON Climate changeInsectsAnimals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates from our environment editor on green issues and actions you can takeInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: while covid itself doesnt discriminate
story: :root Shameful Tory cuts of mental health services have let down a generationOn World Mental Health Day, Dr Rosena Allin-Khan shares what shes seen firsthand on the NHS frontline and what she thinks needs to changeDr Rosena Allin-Khan has kept up regular shts as an NHS hospital doctor since being elected MP Image: Steve BainbridgeopinionByDr Rosena Allin-Khan:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct Ever since I was elected as an MP, Iaposve kept up regular shts as an NHS hospital doctor. Itaposs so important to give something back infor the trust placed in me. But no training could have prepared me for what I experienced during the Covid pandemic. Whether I was treating patients, or serving my constituents in Parliament, my view of le changed fundamentally.We all know the awful toll of statistics: , dead, , hospitalised, over two million estimated to be suffering from the devastating effects of long Covid. But less is known about a serious side-effect of the crisis - its impact on peopleaposs mental health. Inevitably, things have been made worse because of a decade of neglect from the Conservative Government. Waiting lists are soaring, hospital admissions for mental illnesses are up and patients continue to be sent miles away from home for treatment. Shamefully, the Tories have cut a quarter of all mental health beds in England since . Labour would begin to put things right: weaposd guarantee mental health treatment within a month for all who need it, setting a new NHS target, and ensuring that patients start receiving appropriate treatment – not simply an initial assessment of needs – within a month of being referred. Labour would recruit , new staff so that one million more people could access treatment every year by the end of our first term in office and ensure that mental health gets its fair share every time new funding is provided to the NHS.Tory ministers are not taking the action we need to end the mental health crisis. Only Labour will enact the real change needed to improve millions of lives. It breaks my heart, as a frontline medic, to have to tell patients that the services they rely on just are not there anymore, like the addiction support services so many desperately need. With liaison nurses working flat out, emergency departments around the country - often badly short-staffed - have to send home those struggling with addiction and seeking help.This World Mental Health Day the theme is ‘Mental Health in an Unequal World’ – very fitting after the pandemic has laid bare the inequalities we all face, including here in the UK. While the virus itself doesnapost discriminate, it hasnapost hit all of our communities equally. The inequalities are vast and stark. Many of the frontline staff who died from Covid- were Black, Asian and Minority Ethnic.As Doreen Lawrence ’s review showed, the causes of Covid’s disproportionate impact on these communities were systemic. I was told of many incidents, across multiple hospitals, which showed the impact of these structural inequalities on inidual Black hospital housekeeping staff, who were being sent to clean rooms, without protective masks and gowns, after patients had died from Covid.As I saw first-hand in intensive care, row after row of patients were from our Black, Asian and minority ethnic communities. Some of them had, in turn, been caring for our loved ones, stacking our supermarket shelves and keeping our public transport moving.It was the health inequalities that are all too prevalent in our society that permitted the virus to ravage our communities - to the eternal shame of Tory ministers. The knock-on impact on mental health is devastating and is all too visible on the frontline including, for instance, the rising numbers of eating disorders in young Asian women.Extra s must be taken to ensure mental health treatments are tailored for specic communities. When I was training in AE, for example, I learned that in some languages, there isn’t even a word for depression – instead terms such as ‘all-over body pain’ are used to describe a range of mental illnesses. Our communities are being failed - but the Tories donapost care. Only Labour can ensure that proper action is taken before itaposs too late.The Daily Mirror is launching our new campaign HeadStrong: Better Mental Health For All. We’re calling for:Early Access Mental Health Hubs for under s to be rolled out across the country, with at least one for each trust. Waiting times to be cut so people actually start treatment with a professional within four weeks The Govt to fill in the gaps in care - an end of red tape which means many don’t fit the set criteria to get help plus , more mental health staffCompulsory Mental Health education lessons in schools, plus paid counsellors in schools and care homesWant to help  Write to your MP and ask them to support the current Early Day Motion  to debate mental health and the pandemic in parliament. The Government is also letting down a generation of young people. Even before the pandemic, children were being denied desperately needed treatment – in  , % were turned away from mental health services despite a referral from a professional. During the pandemic, this figure has soared to % of our children. They are lost in the system - the hidden victims of the pandemic and a decade of Tory cuts. Their futures are uncertain and the effect on them and their families is appalling. In AE, it often feels that the age of those coming in self-harming or with eating disorders is getting younger and younger. When I first started  years ago, it was not uncommon to see teens, but now my colleagues and I are having to treat far too many young children, often pre-teen, with some as young as . Trust in the system has been entirely degraded over time. How I hate having to be the doctor who tells another teenager that Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services simply can’t come and see them, again.Have you got a story that you think we should feature  Email us at webnews@mirror  All our children deserve proper mental health services so their illnesses can be caught, and treated, as early as possible. That’s why the next Labour Government is committed to providing specialist mental health support in every school, to support pupils and resolve problems before they escalate. Labour would put a full-time mental health professional in every secondary school and a part-time professional in every primary school. For all the children who would feel safer accessing mental health support outside of school, Labour is committed to having an open-access mental health hub for children and young people in every community, providing early intervention and drop-in services.  Throughout the pandemic, our health and care staff have been the glue that have held our country together. The impact that Covid has placed on them, coming after years of erosion of our public services, is taking its toll. Colleagues from across the country are telling me they are burned out, exhausted beyond measure and concerned that the pressure on services means they can’t always give their patients the very best of themselves. Labour announced our Care for Carers package last June, to ensure that all three million health and care staff could get the tailored support they need as a result of the extra pressures they face because of this virus. None of us NHS and care professionals were trained to face this much death. It’s been hugely, but predictably, disappointing then that the Government has persistently ignored our concerns and those of frontline staff across the country – no amount of clapping, however well-intentioned, will ease the burden - only properly tailored support will. Ministers must stop ignoring staff. Otherwise, they shouldn’t be surprised when more and more leave the professions they love so much. I’m proud to support the Mirror’s HeadStrong campaign – it seeks to make such huge progress in reducing the stigma around mental illness, encouraging more people to seek help. We now need a government which will ensure that proper support and treatment is available when people need it the most. This Conservative Government is failing the mental health needs of our country – only Labour has a truly transformative package to tackle one of the most urgent issues of our time. story: :root Primark fan explains best time to shop and why you should never go on weekendsA Primark superfan has revealed the mistakes youre making when visiting the clothing retailer, with the biggest being the day youre deciding to go shopping - and others top secretsBrittany shared her tips Image: brittanyhm TikTokByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Oct | commentsIf youaposve ever wondered why you canapost seem to find the best bargains in your local Primark, then we might have the answer. First of all, you need to go to Primark two to three times a week, minimum, otherwise you will not find the good stuff that I find. So it’s not like my Primark is good, do you know what I mean  I only ever shop in Primark on weekdays. Weekdays is when they have deliveries. story: :root UFO watchers stumped by jaw-dropping clear footage of mystery black shape in the skyThe unexplained UFO sighting in Chicago, Illinois left mum Aiyana "creeped out" and is just one of several reported in the US in recent weeksUFO watchers are stumped after mind-blowing footage captured a strange black shape in the skies Image: Credit: Pen NewsByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Oct | commentsA woman was left in “total confusion” and “creeped out” after she saw a strange black shape floating in the skies. Aiyana, who asked that her second name be withheld, recorded the surreal footage from the roof of her home in Chicago, Illinois. The video shows a long black wishbone shape hanging in the air, with both its wings ending in some sort of sphere. She said: “I literally have no idea what it was. There is nothing comparable. “It was a ball of some sort with two long strings or belts hanging from it. The strings had knobs in the middle and bottom.” Aiyana and her son said neither of them “had any idea what we were seeing”. She said she stayed watching it until it disappeared from view. “It seemed to just float slowly south east without any other major movement,” she said. “It covered a few miles in about  minutes.” “I felt total confusion and a bit creeped out,” she added.Hoping to find answers, a friend shared Aiyana’s footage with UFO watchers online but no one was able to explain how an object could float so calmly above the famously “windy city”.One person wrote: “Iaposve never seen a balloon just hang still in the open air like that. It should bob, evenjust a little. There must be absolutely zero wind there.” Another person described the sighting as “bizarre”, adding: “I have no explanation. It looks like something hanging from a helicopter, except there is no helicopter. “The shape is too weird for it being a balloon, and I think I can also exclude it being an antenna on top of a building in cloud cover – for this, it is way too clearly defined. “I have no idea!”  A third said: “A balloon usually has some movement. I live in Chicago. Even on a still, calm day, Chicago and the surrounding areas have wind of some sort and would move something in the air.” The unexplained sighting is just one of several in the US in recent weeks. Another video, captured in Baltimore, Maryland, attracted a deluge of comments revealing identical sightings in numerous states. In September, a man spotted what appeared to be glowing orange UFOs “flying in formation” when ing home. When he posted the footage online, social media users recalled similar sightings in Washington DC, Las Vegas, St Louis and Detroit. Meanwhile in the UK, a woman was left baffled after capturing an image of a possible UFO hovering in the evening sky over St Helens, Merseyside while taking a friend on a late-night drive.She later toldthe Liverpool Echo :I couldnapost see any lights around it or anything, you can just see the blue thing in the sky. I was just taking a picture of the Moon while we were out because I thought it looked nice.”She added: “We were just like oh, my god, it does look like a UFO. It does look like a ship, it doesnapost look like a plane or a light, it looks like a UFO. I sort of believe in them. Iaposm not a strong believer but I do believe there are aliens out there and stuff like that. It’s interesting. You can see it but it was strange. I believe more now I can see it. story: :root Covid began with Chinese miners in bat caves almost  years ago, expert believesThe Mojiang Miners Passage theory holds that SARS-CoV- derives from tissue samples taken from miners who fell sick working in a bat-infested cave in Medical staff members arrive with a patient at the Wuhan Red Cross Hospital in Wuhan Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsCoronavirus may have originated from labourers who worked in a Chinese mine nearly a decade before the pandemic began, a US expert has claimed.Dr Jonathan Latham, executive director of the US Bioscience Resource Project, believes Covid- may have evolved in the body of infected workers working in the Mojiang mines, in south-central Yunnan in China. In April , six mineworkers were admitted to hospital with coronavirus-like systems after working in a bat-infested cave. Three eventually died. According to Dr Latham, the virus that eventually became SARS-CoV- and caused Covid- may have evolved inside the bodies of these miners before escaping into the population, through samples of the disease that were sent to researchers in Wuhan. The emergence of the Alpha iant in Kent last year from a single immunocompromised patient, he suggests, is evidence that the virus can make “strange evolutionary leaps” when inside an inidual for a long time.  Speaking at a British Medical Journalwebinar, Dr Latham said: The theory requires many hundreds of mutations in one miner to turn into Sars-Cov-. Decades were crammed into about six months. But we have heard of the surprising phenomenon of isolated cases of greatly accelerated evolution in viruses in Britain. As much evolution occurred in that one inidual in England as had occurred in the millions of other infections. Our theory proposes that a similar evolution was happening inside the lungs of miners following the mystery disease in  and argues that the virus leaked from a medical sample obtained from the miners infected by the outbreak. About , kilometres from Wuhan, the Mojiang mines are home to several of the lab origin theories surrounding Covid-. Back in , the workers fell sick after scrubbing a copper seam clean of bat faeces and were admitted to a hospital in the provincial capital of Kunming with persistent coughs, fevers, head and chest pains and breathing dficulties. Medical records at the time concluded the six workers, aged between  and , were victims of a SARS-like coronavirus contracted from horseshoe bats, Reuters reports. When scientists ed to the mine at the end of , they found samples of a pathogen that came to be known as the Mojiang virus”. The Mojiang virus is found in rats and unrelated to SARS-CoV-, and it was not confirmed whether it was behind the miners’ illness. Since then, China’s top bat coronavirus researcher, the Wuhan Institute of VirologyapossShi Zhengli, has said that the workersapos pneumonia-like symptoms were caused by a fungal infection and that there was no sign they had been infected with SARS-CoV-.  But the case of the mineworkers has been used by those supporting the idea that a coronavirus very similar to SARS-CoV- could have been infecting humans as early as . First identied in , a virus named RaTG was discovered from the anus of a horseshoe bat in the same caves. According to a paper by Shi and other researchers, RaTG shares .% of its genome with SARS-CoV- but must have erged  years earlier. The new theory by Dr Latham suggests that the evolution from a virus such as RaTG could have occurred far more quickly inside the body of a miner. Dr Latham said: “We know that coronaviruses were erse and abundant near the mine, and we know that some of the miners underwent y hospitalisations. “Their treatment lasted six months and allowed the evolution of novel adapted human coronaviruses.  “We know many medical samples were sent to the Wuhan institute of Virology, so the question is,what was in the samples, and what was done with any viruses that were found ”China and WIV have strenuously denied allegations that coronavirus escaped from a Wuhan laboratory but Alison Young, the Hurley Chair in Public Affairs Reporting at the Missouri School of Journalism, said lab leaks of dangerous viruses were common throughout the world, thereports. She said: “Lab accidents are not rare. In the US in  there were  reported lab exposure incidences of viruses, bacteria and toxins that the US government regulates. “Lab accidents and exposures happen frequently.” Comment MORE ON British Medical JournalUS Bioscience Inc.SarsCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: designer left covered head toe
story: :root Designer left covered head-to-toe in bandages after fireplace explosionOlivier Rousteing, creative director of fashion house Balmain, shared his ordeal for the first time since suffering severe burns at his home last yearOlivier Rousteing attends the Balmain Homme Menswear Fall Winter - show Image: Getty ImagesByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Oct | commentsA celebrated fashion designer has revealed he was left with severe burns after a fireplace exploded at his home. Olivier Rousteing, creative director of fashion house Balmain, shared a photo of his entire body and head covered in bandages as well as burn marks on his face.The French designer posted the picture on his Instagram account on Saturday, a year exactly after the incident.He said he finally felt ready to share his experience. “I’ve been hiding this for too long and it’s time for you to know,” he wrote. “Exactly a year ago, the fireplace inside my house exploded.”  He said he woke the next day at Parisaposs Hôpital Saint Louis, and has since been recovering from his wounds. He added that he had tried to hide the story of his injuries “from as many people as possible” and had tried to keep the secret with his teams and friends “for too long”. “To be honest I am not really sure why I was so ashamed, maybe this obsession with perfection that fashion is known for and my own insecurities…,” he continued.  Instead, he tried to hide his scars “with face masks, turtlenecks, long sleeves and even multiple rings” in photoshoots and interviews. A year on, Mr Rousteing described himself as “healed, happy and healthy” and thanked the medical staff who had treated him despite dealing with an incredible number of Covid cases at that same time”. Referring to the Balmain Spring Summer  show, he said it was about the celebration of healing over pain and I thank all the models the productions my team the models my Balmain family, my friends that came and supported not only my  years of Balmain but my rebirth.”  He concluded the post by writing: “There is always the sun after the storm.”The designer also shared photos of himself “hiding” in long sleeved clothing and face masks during the summer on his Instagram stories, calling it the “most dficult summer of my le”. At the age of , Mr Rousteing became the youngest and only Black creative director in the history of Balmain. The Bordeaux-born designer marked a decade at the Paris-based fashion house at this yearaposs Fashion Week with a retrospective of his Balmain designs and his spring  collections for women and men. story: :root Shocking photo of ft-long whale crushed and dragged across the Pacic OceanWARNING - DISTRESSING IMAGES The massive five-tonne whale was caught on a tanker that headed across the Pacic Ocean and it was discovered when it went into the port of Mizushima, in Kurashiki city, JapanThe gigantic carcass was found wedged on the vessel Image: Mizushima Coast Guard Station NewsflashByMonica CharsleyNews ReporterTim Hanlon:,  Oct | commentsA -foot whale was found crushed and hanging off the bow of a tanker after being dragged across the Pacic Ocean to Japan. Shocking images show the gigantic carcass found wedged on the vessel as the ship sailed into the port of Mizushima in Kurashiki city last month. The coast guard was alerted to the incident after locals caught sight of the dead whale. Iaposve lived for more than  years, but itaposs my first time [seeing a whale], one eyewitness said, according to the Daily Mail. The Mizushima Coast Guardaposs Office later identied the creature to be a male Bryde whale, weighing in at five tons, reported Insider. Got a story  Email webnews@mirror  The tanker crew was reportedly unaware they had struck the whale and dragged it across the Pacic Ocean, according to Japanese newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun. A spokesperson from the Mizushima Coast Guard Department announced that they would be investigating the incident to prevent it from happening in the future. Michael Fishbach, executive director and co-founder of the Great Whale Conservancy, revealed to Insider that a dozen whales are killed by a ship for each one that is recorded.  He said: Because of the negative buoyancy of the whales, they just sink straight to the bottom after they die, except on rare occasions like this one, where the whales are struck in the centre of their body, and you have a situation as you see in the above image. Thereaposs no question that the number of whales killed by ships each year is in the ,s each year. The whale expert suggested that the number could be decreaseda body was appointed by the industry to approach the shipping companies with a calm, combined effort to put forward measures and changes. Fishbach added that around % of the ships involved in whale strikes are container vessels. two groups, strain and call to each other as they pull a pair of ropes leading into a shed beside the coast, and gradually they heave their leboat out and onto the water.The men are now long dead. This footage, which opens the new RNLI documentary Launch!, comes from the organisation#s impressive archives, and it was shot close to  years ago.It is the clip director Shona Thomson picked to open her film, and she believes it sets the tone for what follows.She said: #It#s just incredible: there must be about  or  men on either side of the boat, pulling it out, and then when it comes back they’re back again, pulling it in.#It’s a really physical image, and it connected with me in terms of what I wanted the film to show – this idea that it really does take a community to launch a leboat.#Launch!, which is to be shown in Aberdeen next weekend, is a documentary quite unlike the ones shown on TV which follow crew members racing to carry out a rescue against the clock.Instead, it spans decades of work by the RNLI#s inspiring volunteers, and as well as showing dramatic shouts, it taps into that deeper concept that Ms Thomson tried to weave throughout the film # community.The organisation#s integral role in Scotland#s coastal communities was a focus from the very start, when the director reached out for permission to stitch those old clips together into a longer-form piece.The RNLI was very keen to provide help, and when  was designated the Year of Coasts and Waters by VisitScotland, several more channels of funding opened up.That, plus access to the Moving Image Archive at the National Library of Scotland, gave Ms Thomson the ability to tell the story of Scotland#s leboats the way she wanted to.Among the clips is a  film called The Ben Barvis, about the Longhope crew on Orkney.Ms Thomson said: #A few years later, there was a rescue that happened, and it actually ended up that most of the crew lost their lives tragically.#You watch The Ben Barvis, and you can see crew that, only a few years later, gave their lives in service.#Another depicts a leboat naming ceremony in Whitehills, Aberdeenshire, from .The director said: #It’s a beautul colour mm film, and the whole town is out there sitting on the quayside. There must be hundreds of people out there, the whole of Whitehills probably.#They#re in their finest clothes, the boat#s there in the harbour, the crew are there with their red woolly hats, and that was shot locally.#I had to ask permission to screen that from a gentleman in Whitehills.#This is another aspect of the community theme: a town that relies heavily on the sea, supporting and celebrating the heroes who carry out rescues when it turns against them.The support carried over beyond the film itself, and into its screenings.Thanks to the fact it is largely based on requests from communities, the production#s cinema tour is dferent from a typical one: There is no date in Glasgow, but there are screenings in Liniclate on Benbecula, Castlebay on Barra and Tighnabruaich in Argyll.Aberdeen#s RNLI branch also asked for the film to come to the city, and Ms Thomson believes that the city stop shows the full breadth of the organisation#s influence.She said: #I think they’re really special screenings that we’ve got in Aberdeen, because perhaps when you think about the RNLI you look at that tour and it is very small places, it’s a coastal community and everybody knows each other.#But Aberdeen#s so dferent – they still do the same incredible job, but it#s a city obviously. The fact that the RNLI are so crucial in the city as well,  I think it’s really important.#The screenings at the Belmont Filmhouse # #such a beautul cinema# # will both be accompanied by QAs with Ms Thomson.She will also be joined by crew from Aberdeen RNLI: on Saturday October , Chloe Urquhart and Mark Gray will be there, and on Sunday October  it will be Ciaran McRae and Andy Haines.A spokeswoman for the RNLI said: #Aberdeen RNLI is delighted to be supporting the Scottish tour of Launch! at the Belmont Filmhouse next weekend and we’re excited to have some of our own volunteer crew on hand on both nights to answer questions about what it’s really like to volunteer for the RNLI.#We’re sure that the event will be an absolute success and we really hope that the local community comes out to see the film.#Tickets are available from the cinema#s website here.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

title: thought for the week september 24 2021
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowI had the wonderful privilege the other week of holding a new grandson for the first time.Isn#t it amazing how a new-born infant can grab hold of your heart  I was filled with so much love and pride and I prayed that his le would be blessed.It so happened that the Gospel reading set for the Sunday after I met my grandson was, in part at least, about a little child.​Mark tells us Jesus was walking ahead of his disciples on the way to Capernaum. When they got there Jesus asked them: #What were you arguing about along the way #They couldn#t answer, for they had been arguing about which of them was the greatest. They were silent, because they#d been caught out.Then Jesus took a little child in his arms and said to them: #Whoever welcomes one such child in my name welcomes me, and whoever welcomes me, welcomes not me but the one who sent me.#Greatness, Jesus was saying to them, is found in welcoming and receiving into our arms someone vulnerable, powerless and dependent, regardless of age.Greatness is found not in what we have accomplished but in what we have done and given to #the least of these#, the hungry, thirsty, naked, sick, and imprisoned: the symbolic children in each of our lives.Greatness never makes itself superior over another. It is not about me, my job, my reputation, my status. Our greatness is revealed in our service and care of others.Max is doing well, by the way, and I can hardly wait to see him again.God bless you and yours, from biggest to littlest, today and always.

title: letters to the editor september 24 2021
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Sir,Dr Jeremy Phillips and Dr Rebecca Helliwell wish to thank the community and patients of Mid Argyll Medical Practice for their kindness and good wishes marking their leaving the practice earlier this month.It has been a real privilege and honour to have been so closely and intimately involved with the lives of so many people and families over the last  and  years respectively.We will always be grateful for this and the opportunity to work with a excellent loyal and dedicated group of staff in the practice, hospital and in the wider NHS team.We will both continue to live locally and continue to work in the NHS in Argyll.Dr Jeremy Phillips and Dr Rebecca HelliwellSir,Looking into the future of marine planning, West Coast Regional Inshore Fisheries Grouphas formed an aquaculture sub-group to foster better communications and understanding between commercial fishing and aquaculture.Both are integral to coastal communities which are economically dependent on them.After the initial meeting it was agreed that there were synergies to be had working with other areas around Scotland, and the group was expanded to become simply the RIFG Aquaculture Working Group.The driving force comes from the proposed huge future expansion of aquaculture, the fact that fishers were not considered, historically, as mandatory consultees and also the promise of a review by Scottish Government of the aquaculture licencing process.It was felt that now was a good time for inshore fishers, through the RIFG, to consider, collate and communicate their views to any, and all, of the regulatory bodies involved in the said licencing process.The working group is particularly concerned with the aquaculture planning process # especially when it comes to the impact of proposed sites on traditional fishing grounds # poor site maintenance and monitoring which can lead to instances of vessel entanglement and also the environmental impact of the sites on both commercial and non-commercial species.The group believes that while the sector has made many advances over the past decade, increased transparency and oversight are needed to ensure the aquaculture sector can better co-exist with the fishing industry.The initial aim of the group would be to ensure that there is a proper analysis of localised fishing and follow up with clear and sensible communication between the two sectors to ensure that with expansion does not come conflict.It is a timeous idea, which will hopefully reassure fishermen that they will not simply be displaced by fish farming but will be respected for their own produce.The group will cement a policy to assist the fishing industry deal realistically with the fish farming industry and the Scottish Salmon Producers Organisation.Simon Macdonald, chair RIFG Aquaculture Work GroupSir,NFU Scotland is calling on the UK Government to address the nation’s growing labour crisis, which is undermining all parts of the food and drink supply chain, leading to signicant losses on some Scottish farms and resulting in a growing number of empty shop shelves.Last week#s #BackBritishFarmingDay on September  came as a UK Government announcement of a free trade #agreement in principle# between the UK and New Zealand is believed to be imminent.Having agreed in June to provide unfettered access in the future to Australia, the cumulative impact of another deal with a major exporting nation has huge signicance for Scottish farmers and crofters.With so much to celebrate about the quality and standards of our food and drink, #BackBritishFarmingDay was a fantastic opportunity to thank the nation for their incredible support throughout Brexit and Covid-.NFU Scotland, both independently and in conjunction with the Scottish food and drink industry, has written several times to UK Government calling for measures that address the shortfall in both seasonal and permanent staff.Should it fail to do so, I have absolutely no doubt that the situation will deteriorate further.It is galling to hear that the UK Government is on the verge of signing up to another free trade deal that will permit a growing level of imports while delivering very little to our food and drink sector in .The blunt fact is that neither deal has been afforded any kind of proper parliamentary scrutiny as the government’s promised Statutory Trade and Agriculture Commission has yet to be established.Safeguards against market disruption are also promised, but the cumulative impact of these deals will be profound for UK farming.If handled badly, these may make it impossible for some of our family farming businesses to continue to compete with high levels of low-cost imports produced to standards that would not be allowed here.Martin Kennedy, president, NFU ScotlandSir,National audits of diabetic services have shown that only around  per cent of people with type one or two diabetes have nine key annual checks to help prevent long-term diabetic complications.The pandemic has made this situation dficult because many routine checks and face-to-face appointments have not been available.The InDependent Diabetes Trusthas published a free new booklet which explains the nine key tests.It helps people look after their health by ensuring that they know what checks they need from health professionals.Get your copy of Diabetes care # your  key checks by contacting IDDT on  , emailing enquiries@iddtinternational.org or writing to IDDT, PO Box , Northampton NN XS.Jenny Hirst, InDependent Diabetes Trust

title: thought for the week october 1 2021
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowInsects are tiny creatures, but they make a massive contribution in keeping our world in balance.They are responsible for the pollination of about  per cent of trees and bushes on the entire planet. Yet we often treat them in a dismissive way.Let#s think about some insects.Take the bluebottle. How often has it outwitted us with its amazing flight paths, ducking and ing to avoid our threatening gestures.While we have developed some of the most sophisticated flying machines the world has known, none can match the bluebottle in its agility.We have mentioned pollination. What insect is more important than the bee as it goes about its business from flower to flower ensuring that the plants will produce seed for another year and giving us honey as a product of its labours.How beautul too are its colours and the structure of its body – a remarkable little insect.Then there is the humble moth and its gravity-defying antics walking across ceilings. It has a very fragile body but in its short le can nevertheless act out its own acrobatic skill in an amazing performance.Or we may think of the spider and the beauty of its web, perhaps seen on a frosty winter morning. A true work of art woven with such delicacy.In the bible we read this: #Go watch the ants, you lazy person. Watch what they do and be wise. Ants have no commander, no leader or ruler, but they store up food in the summer and gather their supplies at harvest.# From this we can learn four things helpful to living: be diligent and hard-working have an #I can do it# attitude plan ahead remember teamwork is important.

title: pines-burn-wind-farm-extension-plans-backed-council
story: CONCERNS have been raised that the council is ldquosetting a precedent as a five-year extension to a Borders wind farm was approved.Approval for  turbines at Pines Burn, near Hawick, was granted in  following an appeal to Scottish Government by Energiekontor UK.The operational le in the original application was  years, but Scottish Borders Councilrsquosplanning and building standards committee gave a five-year extension the green light on Monday .During the meeting, Duncan Taylor, of Energiekontor, said that lower power prices, expensive grid costs and ldquogenerally higher costs all round had led to the extension bid.:Father and son told to pay pound, in compensation to man after Borders assaultldquoOur ducks are in a row and wersquove committed millions to this project, he said. ldquoWe just need a leg up from you [SBC] so that the Pines Burn consent can benefit from modern turbine technologies.On the turbines, SBC principal planning officers Barry Fotheringham said: ldquoIf they are considered acceptable for  years then they should be acceptable for  years.Although the extension was passed by the committee, it did not receive unanimous support.Hawick councillor Neil Richards, of the Conservatives, said: ldquoIt [the report] says, lsquoAfter  years affected receptors will be accustomed to experiencing the wind farmrsquo, well I would like to beg to dfer on that.ldquoWhy not  years, why not   When are we getting the concrete out the ground and restoring the site  Twenty five years is good enough for me.:Borders motorists warned about closures on major road in  locations this monthEast Berwickshire councillor Jim Fullarton, also of the Conservatives, said he was ldquovery concerned by the extension application.ldquoWe need to be very careful here, he told the meeting. ldquoFive years sounds very reasonable but are we setting a precedent ldquoOther wind farm operators will be going, lsquoIf they can do it, letrsquos go for  yearsrsquo.Responding to the concerns, Mr Fotheringham said: ldquoI donrsquot think it will open the door for further applications butit does we would have to assess any application on its own merits.:Vehicle left damaged after lsquodangerous driving incidentrsquo in Borders, say policeHe added that Fallago Rig, Whitelaw Brae and Dunlaw ndash all Borders wind farms ndash have received extensions from either Scottish ministers or SBC.ldquoThese extensions are something we need to start considering going forward, said Mr Fotheringham. ldquoNot only are turbines getting bigger, they are getting longer lespans.Registering his approval, Galashiels councillor Andy Anderson, of the SNP, said: ldquoI would rather see a wind farm continue over a longer period rather than look at a new position for wind farms.On the extension, Tweeddale West councillor Eric Small, of the Conservatives, added: ldquoThe costs are escalating daily and itrsquos a way for wind farms to spread the costs.

title: mountain-biker-darren-transferred-edinburgh-royal-infirmary
story: A GALASHIELS mountain biker who was injured in a crash while competing in a world championship event in Switzerland has been repatriated back to Scotland.Darren Scott suffered two broken ribs and damage to his back and pancreas in the smash which took place on  September.The -year-old former Scottish masters champion also sustained internal bleeding and a clot developed in his chest preventing his .An issue with his insurance meant that he was not covered in that country so his friend Sean Doherty who had been paralysed in a motorbike crash six-years ago resurrected his own fundraising account on the  Foundation website.Within the space of a week, an incredible pound, was donated to help with costs.After almost a month in the Swissrsquo hospital Darrenrsquos injuries stabilised allowing his transfer to the Royal Infirmary in Edinburgh for further assessment and to begin his long road to recovery.Speaking from his hospital bed ahead of histo Scotland Darren told us: ldquoI canrsquot get over how generous people have been. Irsquod like to thank everyone who has donated as well as everyone who got in touch to wish me well because it was a pretty rough time for the first few days. Irsquod also like to thank people across here who helped at the time and looked after my bike.A statement on the  Foundation website stated: ldquoWe are delighted he is back in the UK closer to family and friends. We are very grateful for the medical attention he was given in Switzerland and is now receiving in Scotland.ldquoIt has been an extremely stressful time for Darren and the whole family but we have been very much humbled and comforted by the support shown to us by so many people. We would like to thank everyone for their kind wishes and donations, they are all very much appreciated.ldquoAs soon as the doctors have finished their assessment of his condition and formulated a treatment plan for Darrenrsquos recovery, we will issue further updates.ldquoThank you all so much.At the time of the crash Darren was in overall third place in the World Enduro Championships having made the podium in France and was looking forward to the final event of the season at Innerleithen.Despite missing out on that race,his efforts throughout the season saw him finish in overall fourth position.Hundreds of friends have taken to social media to wish him well and Darren is keen to fully recover and get back on his bike.

title: gala-fairydean-rovers-take-honours-gretna
story: TWO goals in the opening  minutes at Raydale Park on Wednesday evening put Gala Fairydean Rovers firmly on the path to their fth win on the bounce.Gretna - who had just announced Stephen Hatfield as their new manager - forced three corners in the opening stages as they aimed to make an instant impression for their new boss.But Gala weathered the initial storm and with just four minutes on the clock Calum Hall cut in from the left and drilled a -yard pile-driver into the bottom corner of the net.After that, the visitors totally dictated the play, pinning Gretna back deep into their own half with skipper Jack Beaumont spraying passes across the park as Gala probed and pressed for the breakthrough.And it came on the ninth minute mark when Ciaren Chalmers burst through the home defence and his shot squeezed over the line.The dominance continued and a third goal arrived in the rd minute when Zander Murray spectacularly erted a Beaumont delivery into the roof of the net with a volley.After the interval Gretna retreated into their own half to try and keep the score down and the plan worked.Although Gala should have scored a fourth on the hour mark when they were awarded a penalty for handball.Daryl Healys spot kick lacked power and the Gretna keeper pulled off a fine save.Gala continued to dominate but Gretna were dangerous on the break and almost pulled one back when a shot struck the inside of the post but bounced back along the line.And Gala had keeper Dean Beveridge to thank for a brilliant slide tackle to foil a Gretna forward who had evaded the offside trap.However, the visitors were coasting to victory with Gregor Jordan and Lewis Hall outstanding at the back with the game outcome out of sight.Unfortunately, a stramash in the Gala goalmouth in injury time as a corner was about to be delivered ended the game on an ugly note.The result was four yellow cards - two for each team - with one of them to Gala right back Sean Docherty, currently on loan from Hearts, but as he had been booked earlier he ultimately received a red card which was a disappointing end to the game.With five wins in a row, Gala now have a huge Lowland League encounter against Civil Service Strollers at Netherdale on SaturdayThe Edinburgh side are the surprise packets of the Lowland League this season and are currently deservedly fourth in the table with another midweek win against Caledonian Braves. But with Gala hard on their heels, Saturdays game will be a huge test for both teams.
